title: Urban–rural political divide
text:
In <a href="political%20science">political science</a>, the urban–rural political divide is a phenomenon in which predominantly <a href="Urban%20area">urban areas</a> and predominantly <a href="Rural%20area">rural areas</a> within a country have sharply diverging political views. It is a form of <a href="political%20polarization">political polarization</a>. Typically, urban areas exhibit more <a href="Liberalism">liberal</a>, <a href="Left-wing%20politics">left-wing</a>, <a href="Cosmopolitanism">cosmopolitan</a> and/or <a href="Multiculturalism">multiculturalist</a> political attitudes, while rural areas exhibit more <a href="Conservatism">conservative</a>, <a href="Right-wing%20politics">right-wing</a>, <a href="Right-wing%20populism">right-wing populist</a> and/or <a href="Nationalism">nationalist</a> political attitudes.
An urban–rural political divide has been observed worldwide in many nations including the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>, the <a href="United%20Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>, <a href="France">France</a>, <a href="Hungary">Hungary</a>, <a href="Poland">Poland</a>, <a href="Belgium">Belgium</a>, <a href="Italy">Italy</a>, the <a href="Netherlands">Netherlands</a>, <a href="Turkey">Turkey</a>, <a href="Thailand">Thailand</a>, and the <a href="Philippines">Philippines</a>. Political divisions between urban and rural areas have been noted by political scientists and journalists to have intensified in the <a href="21st%20century">21st century</a>, and in particular since the <a href="Great%20Recession">Great Recession</a>. In <a href="Europe">Europe</a>, the increasing urban-rural polarization has coincided with the decline of <a href="Centre-left%20politics">center-left</a> parties and concomitant rise of <a href="Far-left%20politics">far-left</a> and <a href="Far-right%20politics">far-right</a> parties, a trend known as <a href="Pasokification">Pasokification</a>.
